questions.text: A 20 year old male patient presented with patchy alopecia. The histopathology is shown below. What is the treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
• Non-scarring patchy alopecia + peribulbar lymphocytic infiltrate showing the characteristic swarm of bees appearance - diagnosis of Alopecia areata
  • Treatment in this - Intra-lesional triamcinolone injection
  • Trichotillomania will also be patchy alopecia but biopsy will show trichomalacia and perifollicular haemorhhages
  • Tinea capitis also presents with patchy alopecia and hpe shows folliculitis with special stain showing hyphae.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with chronic history of recurrent, painful nodules which rupture to form sinus tract in axilla and groin. Which structure is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis Suppurativa

  • Apocrine glands & hair follicle occlusion
  • Site : A N G
  • Comedones, Nodules, abscesses, sinuses, scars
  • Aka : Inverse Acne
  • Image shows multiple nodules, abscesses and scarring in the axillae, s/o diagnosis of Hidradenitis suppurativa,
  • IT is due to involvement of hair follicles and apocrine glands
  • Hidradenitis suppurativa (acne inversa) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition of follicular and apocrine gland occlusion with lesions including deep-seated nodules and abscesses, draining sinus tracts or fistulae, and fibrotic scars
  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is characterized by comedolike follicular occlusion, chronic relapsing inflammation, mucopurulent discharge, and progressive scarring.

choices.text: Grattage test, pinpoint bleeding, Guttate psoriasis
KOH, spaghetti and meatballs, Pityriasis versicolor
Peripheral collarette, hanging curtain sign, Pityriasis rosea
Slit skin smear, AFB, indeterminate hansens

questions.text: 20 year old boy presents with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the upper back. What is the correct answer ?
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis versicolor, is a frequent, benign, superficial fungal infection of the skin.
  • Pityriasis versicolor is caused by Malassezia, a dimorphic lipophilic fungus, also known as Pityrosporum. It is a component of normal skin flora
  • The main species : Malassezia furfur, Malassezia globose
  • Malassezia can cause pityriasis versicolor when it converts to its pathogenic filamentous form.
  • CF : multiple, well-demarcated, oval, finely scaling patches. Skin lesions may be hypopigmented, hyperpigmented
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by microscopic examination of scales soaked in potassium hydroxide examination, which demonstrates the typical grape-like clusters of yeast cells and long hyphae
  • Woods lamp : pale yellow fluorescence
  • Topical & oral medications used . Antifungal agents include imidazole (clotrimazole 1%, ketoconazole 2%, econazole, isoconazole, miconazole), ciclopirox olamine 1%, oral azoles. Some nonspecific antifungal agents (sulfur plus salicylic acid, selenium sulfide 2.5%, and zinc-pyrithione also used.
  • Terbinafine and griseofulvin not used.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology. 9th Edition. Page 32.10-32.13

questions.text: A gardener having history of trauma on hand, presents with skin lesions as shown below. What will the finding on biopsy ?
questions.solution:
• Farmer with history of trauma can develop a subcutaneous mycosis
  • Here, the image shows multiple nodulo-ulcerative lesions in a linear pattern.
  • Sporotrichosis can be considered as a DD here
  • HPE will show Typical Asteroid bodies.
  • Asteroid bodies are star-shaped inclusions in the cytoplasm of multinucleated giant cells. Centre has the yeast, surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material
  • Differential Diagnosis of Subcutaneous Nodules With SporotrichoidSpread
  • Sporothrixschenckii
  • atypical mycobacteria - Mycobacterium marinum
  • Nocardiosis
  • Tularemia

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful blisters on erythematous base as shown in the image. What is the causative organism ?
questions.solution:
• Grouped painful vesicles on vermilion border of lips - herpes labialis
  • Caused by Herpes simplex virus 1
  • Latency : Trigeminal ganglion - reactivates to cause recurrent episodes
  • Molluscipox virus -, caused by molluscipox virus. Pearly white dome shaped papules with central umbilication, scattered around the mouth. No vesicles seen
  • Varicella zoster virus : reactivation of Varicella zoster virus. Grouped painful vesicles, unilateral, in dermatomal distribution
  • Coxsackie A16 virus : Caused by coxsackie A16. painful vesicles on palate, hands, foot mouth

questions.text: A LL Hansens patient on treatment since 2 months presents with fever and skin lesions as shown. What will be the approach to treatment?
questions.solution:
1. A patient of LL Hansens on starting treatment is at risk of developing leprosy reaction.
  2. Fever with classic erythematous tender nodules over the body is s/o Erythema nodosum leprosum, Type 2 leprosy reaction
  3. Can be accompanied with systemic features of fever, arthralgia, hepatitis, uveitis and orchitis.
  4. MBMDT has to be continued in all patients
  5. Treatment of ENL must be individualized.
  6. If ENL is mild - it may be treated with antipyretics alone.
  7. Moderate-severe skin lesions, fever, malaise, and other tissue involvement - Prednisolone.
  8. Successful therapy is defined by the cessation of skin lesion development and the disappearance of the systemic signs and symptoms.
    • Thalidomide - most effective drug in leprosy T2R but it is not DOC.
    • The mechanism of thalidomide’s dramatic action against ENL is reduction of TNF levels and IgM synthesis and its slowing of polymorphonuclear leukocyte migration. (Dose - 200 - 400mg/day)

choices.text: Giemsa stain of lymph node aspirate

questions.text: A 23-year-old truck driver presents with a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans with painless inguinal swelling. The most appropriate diagnostic test is:
questions.solution:
• The case history points towards syphilis.
  • In this case next best step, would be to do dark field microscopy
  • Darkfield examination by microscope allows for direct examination of spirochetes from the mucosal lesion and thus offers an immediate diagnosis if positive 
  • Test to rule out other STI should be done if feasible .
  • Inj Benzathine penicillin 2.4 mIU is the treatment of choice
  • Syphilis is a bacterial infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum
  • Primary syphilis appears 10 to 90 days after exposure to the infection and comprises a painless, indurated ulcer (chancre) at the site of inoculation with the T. pallidum.
  • Regional lymphadenopathy is common and consists of rubbery lymph nodes.
  • The chancre oozes serum, which is teeming with treponema

questions.text: A patient with a 10 year history of asymptomatic red scaly skin lesions now presents with painful swollen fingers and pain in wrist joint. What is the treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
The majority of patients have psoriasis prior to the onset of arthritis. In 70% of patients, the skin features of psoriasis develop prior to joint disease, in 20% of patients, the joint disease presents fi rst and in 10% the skin and joints are affected concurrently There is an association between more severe cutaneous psoriasis and the development of psoriatic arthritis.

The prevalence of psoriatic arthritis is also increased in patients with nail and scalp psoriasis Early morning back stiffness may be the only clinical feature of sacro-iliitis or cervical spondylitis. Heel pain (a manifestation of enthesitis of the Achilles tendon) or plantar fasciitis may also be a presenting feature.

Clinical examination may reveal evidence of dactylitis (sausage fingers) or swollen or tender joints. This may affect one joint in an asymmetric pattern or several joints simultaneously.

In such patients with psoriasis vulgaris and psoriatic arthritis - treatment of choice : Methotrexate

REFERENCE: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 35, page 35.43

questions.text: A patient presented with oral ulcers since 3 months and flaccid bullae with painful red raw erosions on the skin since 1 month. Characteristic microscopic feature of this disease is:
questions.solution:
• Clinical Presentation of Pemphigus - oral ulcer with bullae, positive nikolsky sign
  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Supra basal split
  • Nikolsky sign
  • Bulla-spread sign
  • Scalp, face, trunk, mucosal lesions
  • Pemphigus vegetans: Supra basal split
  • Heaped-up vegetating lesions
  • Groins, axilla, angles of mouth, mucosal
  • Pemphigus foliaceus: Split in granular layer, just below S.corneum
  • Superficial bullae rupture to form crusts/ scales . No mucosal inv
  • Pemphigus erythematosus: Split in granular layer or just below stratum corneum
  • Less severe form of P. foliaceus
  • Dry, hyperkeratotic lesions on face (malar region)

questions.text: A 28 yr old patient presents with multiple itchy, grouped papulovesicular lesions and excoriations on elbow, knees, buttocks and upper back. Direct immunofluorescence from shows IgA deposition. Which serological investigation will be done?
questions.solution:
• multiple itchy, grouped papulovesicular lesions and excoriations on elbow, knees, buttocks and upper back along with IgA deposition in Direct immunofluorescence is s/o Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • DH is known to be associated with coeliac disease/gluten sensitive enteropathy and testing for the same is done
  • The American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) recommends that antibody testing, especially immunoglobulin A anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody (IgA TTG), is the best first test for suspected celiac disease.

questions.text: A 10 year old child presented with unilateral depigmented lesion. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• unilateral depigmented lesion with leukotrichia(white hair can be seen in the eyebrows and eyelashes ) in 10 year old child is s/o a diagnosis of segmental vitiligo
  • Nevus depigmentosus : present since birth and size increases with age. It also does not have leukotrichia
  • Piebaldism : AD, family H +. characterized by isolated congenital leukoderma (white skin) with islands of sparing and poliosis (white hair) in a distinct ventral midline pattern.
  • Hypomelanosis of ITO : Hypopigmented whorled streaks, unilateral in blaschkoid pattern

choices.text: Adhesive in the bindi is the main source of the chemical
Paraphenyldiamine is causative agent in the glue
Pathogenesis of disease is a Type 4 hypersensitivity

questions.text: Which of these is false about the disorder shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis - Allergic contact dermatitis due to bindi
  • The sticker type of bindi is the main cause, and the causative agent is PTBP present in high concentration in the glue. Causes ACD by Type 4 HSN
  • Difficult to treat, topical steroids may help
  • Also, chemical is a known melanocytotoxic agent and causes depigmentation. No melanocytes in the lesion leading to bindi leucoderma

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with fever and joint pains was prescribed medicnes and 7 days later, she presents with skin lesion as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Fever + Joint pains
  • Patint could have been prescribed NSAIDS which can cause a drug eruption - fixed drug eruption.
  • Lesions typically have a round to oval shape and are violaceous in color.
  • Melasma - brown, bilaterally symmetrical. No relation to fever/drug
  • Chik sign - speckled asymmetrical brown pigmentation on nose of a patient who has suffered from chikangunya. It does not have round well defined shape
  • Nevus of ota-blue grey pigmentation on unilateral face, in area supplied by ophthalmic/maxillary division

choices.text: Tell the patient to avoid sunlight
Follow the lesion for any evidence of growth

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with a lesion on the upper back. The next step in management is:
questions.solution: • Suspect malignancy due to changes in the lesion and next step is doing a full thickness biopsy to confirm diagnosis of melanoma

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Retinoids in dermatology

  • acitretin : psoriasis, pityriasis rubra pilaris, congenital ichthyosis
  • isotretinoin : severe nodular acne
  • Tretinoin : Acne, photodamaged skin
  • Adapalene : Acne
  • Tazarotene : psoriasis, acne, photodamaged skin
  • Alitretinoin : Kaposi's sarcoma, chronic hand eczema
  • Bexarotene : cutaneous Lymphoma

questions.text: A 18 year old boy presents with history of intractable seizures. What is the drug that should not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts - multiple skin colored to hyperpigmented papules on central face. These are Adenoma Sebaceoum. Along with history of intractable seizures, This is seen in tuberous sclerosis
  • Manifestation of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex
    • Seizures
    • Mental retardation
    • Retinal & optic nerve hamartomas
    • Achromic retinal patches
    • Involvement of skull, spine and pelvis
    • Dental pits
    • Tumors of heart (rhabdomyomas)
  • Reddish papules on face - adenoma sebaceoum
  • Periungual fibroms, also called as koenons tumors

Treatment

  • The main complication of TSC requiring long-term medical therapy is epilepsy. Antiepileptic medications (AEDs) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with TSC. Vigabatrinis the drug of first choice for children with TSC and infantile spasms. Topiramate, lamotrigine, valproate, and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)/steroids are also useful.
  • Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, and phenytoin may cause exacerbation of seizures, particularly in younger children and infants,
  • Everolimus tablets and tablets for suspension (Afinitor and Afintiro Disperz) are approved in the US for SEGAs, partial-onset seizures associated with tuberous sclerosis. Afinitor is also approved in adults with TSC-associated renal angiomyolipoma, not requiring immediate surgery.
  • facial angiofibromas - Laser therapy, topical rapamycin

questions.text: A 70 year old lady patient presented with multiple erythematous scaly lesions over the body since many years. The histopathology is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Elderly patient with red scaly lesions on the body with biopsy findings showing lymphocytic aggregates within the superficial dermis and small clusters in the epidermis(Pautrier microabscesses).
  • This is s/o diagnosis of Mycosis Fungoides
  • Mycosis fungoides is an indolent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (indolent coursE. but is inevitably fatal (not easily amenable to treatment).
  • MF is the most common primary cutaneous lymphoma.
  • Pautrier microabscess is characteristic of MF.

a. Psoriasis vulgaris - Red scaly lesions will be seen but biopsy findings will be very different. Munros abscess and kogoj pustules - both are neutrophilic abscesses. Hypogranulosis, parakeratosis and regular elongation of the rete ridges will be seen

b. Squamous cell carcinoma - will not present with this clinical features/biopsy

c. Tinea corporis - Red scaly lesions that will be itchy. Itching as a symptom not mentioned here. HPE shows spongiosis, parakeratosis, hyphae

questions.text: A 50 year old patient, resident of West Bengal presented with spotty hyperpigmentation on back, scaly lesions on palms and nail findings as shown. Identify the nail condition:
questions.solution:
• Image shows white transverse lines on the nails, parallel to the lunula.
  • Along with history of residence in Bengal, spotty hyperpigmentation on back (Guttate hyperpigmentation), scaly lesion on palms and soles (Arsenical keratoses) - Chronic arsenic poisoning.
  • Arsenic (As) is a nearly tasteless odorless toxic metalloid element that is found ubiquitously in the environment.
  • Chronic arsenic exposure through contaminated drinking supply is a global health concern. However, geographic distribution has a significant impact on contamination rates.
  • Multiple dermatologic signs -, spotted hyperpigmentation on body in a "raindrop appearance".
  • Mees lines occur in approximately 5% of patients. Mee's lines show a 1 to 2mm wide transverse white bands across the fingernails presents 4 to 6 weeks after exposure.
  • Other dermatologic signs include palmer-planter hyperkeratosis, eczematoid lesions, warts, and alopecia.
  • Arsenic exposure has links to squamous cell carcinoma secondary to hyperkeratosis.

questions.text: A 39 year old patient with long standing insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and Hashimoto thyroiditis presented with these lesions on the shin. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is asymptomatic.
  • Patients usually present with shiny, asymptomatic patches that slowly enlarge over months to years.
  • The patches are initially red-brown and progress to yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques. Ulcerations can occur, typically after trauma and occasionally with associated pain.
  • Most cases of necrobiosis lipoidica occur on the pretibial area
  • Main findings on histopathology - granulomas, thickening of the blood vessel walls and endothelial cell swelling found in the middle to deep dermis, characteristics shared with diabetic microangiopathy.

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disease
Loss of function mutation of F-12 is seen in patients having type III disease
Associated with mutations of SERPING1 gene
All types aggravated by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent attacks of swelling as shown in picture. All of the following statements are false regarding this diseases except
questions.solution:
• Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE) is associated with mutation in SERPING1 gene, which provides
    instructions for making a protein called C1 inhibitor.
    • Types I and II HAE are inherited as an autosomal dominant trait on chromosome 11q 12.1.
    • Gain-of-function mutations of F12 that have been described in about 20% of patients with type III HAE.
    • All types of HAE are aggravated by Oestrogen in contraceptive and hormone replacement therapies
